in treats made of honey covered fruit and nuts in the Middle Ages Europeans made candy from boiled sugar but the high cost of imported cane sugar restricted this delicacy to the wealthy candy finally became affordable for the masses in the 1800s with the discovery of a new and domestic source of sugar the sugar beet these hard candies aren't mass-produced confections they are gourmet candies custom made and crafted by hand the candy maker starts by bringing a pot of sugar and water to a boil then he adds glucose a thick syrup made from starch he heats the mixture to a specific temperature depending on what type of candy he's making and lets it cook for about a half hour then he stirs in liquid flavoring once the mixture is evenly blended he pours it on to a cooling table the candy maker has several flavorings at his disposal from eucalyptus oil to fruit flavors he also chooses from a wide range of food colorings this candy will have a strawberry design in the middle so he and his assistants are working with three colors green for the leaves red for the berry and yellow for the background [Music] to enhance the flavor they add citric acid then they keep blending until the candy has cooled down and hardened enough to be malleable they separate the pieces by color and put each piece on a heated table to slow the hardening process so that the candy will remain pliable now they create the design they form various shapes and sizes and like a puzzle put the pieces together to make a jumbo version of the candy design [Music] once they've assembled the red berry and green leaves and yellow background they roll on more yellow background then a layer of red for the outside trim all that's left is to reduce this giant wad of candy into a bite-sized version to do that the candy maker pinches one end and stretches it out to form a long uniform strand called a rod he cuts the rod into pieces 60 centimetres long but he has to keep rolling them until they cool and Harden or else they'll go flat when the rod is just the right diameter the design is in perfect proportion all they have to do now is cut candy sized pieces they use the same technique to make kiwi candy pink grapefruit candy and banana candy to name just a few varieties want to order up some candy with a personalized message here's an L an o avi and II a y/o and you again they create a yellow background and red trim then it's more pinching pulling rolling and cutting until the rods are down to just the right size if you look at the back end of each rod you'll see the lettering in Reverse that'll be the underside of the candy when the raw candy comes off the cooling table it's transparent to make it opaque or to lighten the color they pull it on a hook here they intertwine two colors and feed the rod through a special machine that forms bands of pillow shaped candies after cooling they simply break them apart by hand if you're no sucker for hard candies no problem they can also twist rods into lollipops [Music] you

became affordable for the masses in the 1800s with the discovery of a new and domestic source of sugar the sugar beet these hard candies aren't mass-produced confections their gourmet candies custom-made and crafted by hand the candy maker starts by bringing a pot of sugar and water to a boil then he adds glucose a thick syrup made from starch he heats the mixture to a specific temperature depending on what type of candy he's making and lets it cook for about a half hour then he stirs in liquid flavoring once the mixture is evenly blended He pours it onto a cooling table the candy maker has several flavorings at his disposal from eucalyptus oil to fruit flavors he also chooses from a wide range of food colorings this candy will have a strawberry design in the middle so he and his assistants are working with three colors green for the leaves red for the berry and yellow for the background to enhance the flavor they add citric acid then they keep blending until the candy has cooled down and hardened enough to be malleable they separate the pieces by color and put each piece on a heated table to slow the hardening process so that the candy will remain pliable now they create the design they form various shapes and sizes and like a puzzle put the pieces together to make a jumbo version of the candy design once they've assembled the red berry and green leaves and yellow background they roll on more yellow background then a layer of red for the outside trim all that's left is to reduce this giant wad of candy into a bite-sized version to do that the candy maker pinches one end and stretches it out to form a long uniform strand called a rod he cuts the ride into pieces almost 2 feet long but he has to keep rolling them until they cool and Harden or else they'll go flat when the rod is just the right diameter the design is in perfect proportion all they have to do now is cut candy sized pieces they use the same technique to make Kiwi candy pink grapefruit candy and banana candy to name just a few varieties want to order up some candy with a personalized message here's an al I know a V Andy oh why oh and you again they create a yellow background and red trim then it's more pinching pulling rolling and cutting until the rods are down to just the right size if you look at the back end of each rod you'll see the lettering is in Reverse that'll be the underside of the candy when the wrong candy comes off the cooling table is transparent to make it opaque or light in the color they'll pull it on a hook here they intertwine two colors and feed the rod through a special machine that forms bands of pillow shaped candies after cooling they simply break them apart by hand it's your new sucker for hard candies no problem they can also twist rods into lollipops if you have any comments about the show or if you'd like to suggest topics for future shows drop us a line at Science Channel com /how it's made

when I was a little girl I was
completely obsessed with candy I remember constantly begging my dad for
a dollar so I could get on my bike race as fast as I could to our local
convenience store where I would purchase as much candy as I possibly could for

memory of my younger obsession I figured we would switch up a few things and
we would make some liquor lollipops in this video we are going to make some
margarita flavor so let's go spice things up so on medium heat I'm going
to add 3 cups of sugar 1/2 a cup of corn syrup and now 3/4 cup of the tequila mix okay so now stir this until the sugar
kind of dissolves and then to add a little bit of color and a little bit of
flavor I'm going to add the strawberry syrup and then one more teaspoon and
then stir it real quick and as you see it has started to bubble so now that it
started to bubble we will want to stop stirring this and just let it bubble up
and you'll want to take your candy thermometer and just check the
temperature and once it reaches 320 degrees we can add the liquor okay so
in the meantime while your mixture is reaching a high temperature you want to
get like a pan and line it with parchment paper or you can get some
silicone molds and just spray them with some cooking spray because you are
gonna have to work really fast and so you want everything prepared and then
you want to get some sucker sticks also you can use skewers if you want and just
cut them down alright that's looking pretty good between 300 to 310 is the
hard crack stage that's why you want it to reach 320 okay so for the last
ingredient so now that this has reached the hard crack stage now we are going to
add some tequila this is just cheap tequila it doesn't have to be anything
fancy and you'll want to add 1/4 cup of tequila and then I'm just gonna give
that one last stir to mix the tequila in and then I'm gonna check the temperature
real quick and you want to make sure it reaches 310 again alright guys if you
can see it's pretty much there at the 310 mark and just in case you're
wondering it is kind of a long process it does take a while for it to heat up
to the hard crack stage and then once you put the alcohol in it takes a
little bit for it to heat back up to the hard crack stage as well but once it
reaches 310 you can go ahead and just turn your burner off and then this is
when you will want to work really fast so that you get perfect little
lollipops because it definitely hardens really
fast so I'm just going to pour mine right into the measuring cup so it'll be
easy to work with okay so we're going to try really fast to pour it into the mold and then for the parchment paper you can
just go ahead and just try to make little circles and then I'm just going
to take some margarita salt and just put it on the top makes it a little pretty
and really gives it that margarita drink taste and then you can take your sucker
stick and just put them just kind of twirl it around like this and make sure
it really gets into your syrup and then I'm just gonna lay my sucker sticks like
this because obviously these aren't real sucker candy molds but you can always
buy those at the store they actually do sell sucker molds but the whole point is
just showing you you can really use whatever works for you or if you just
want hard candy you don't even have to add the sucker sticks it can just be
hard candy okay so you can just leave it on the counter for about 10 to 20
minutes until they hardened or if you want it done faster you can just put it

the heat and add in flavouring, for this one I am using musk. Split it into two sections and add red colouring
to one half and blue into the other. We are going to take the blue half and pull
it and stretch it to make it opaque but with the red half we are just going to leave that
and not pull it all. Keep pulling the blue half and twisting it
so that you can see there the more we pull it and the more we twist it the more opaque
and shiny it becomes. Don't pull the red half just cut it in half
to make two long cylinders. Pull the blue into two long snakes too and
then stack them up to make a square. It looks a bit like toothpaste. Squeeze them together to round it out and
then cut that into two. Working with one half pull it and make it
thinner into a nice thin long stick. And you can slice it while ti is warm to make
individual candies OR to make the spirals, wrap it around a thick skewer. Once it is all the way to the end you can
just pull the skewer out and leave those to cool. See how the pink there is totally transparent
because we didn't pull it and the blue is opaque. The other thing you can do is roll some of
this mixture into a ball and make round lollipops and just put a stick in one end. And you can make as many different candies
as you like just by flavouring and colouring each one differently. And now for something which is going to be
hard to do without a heat lamp but I reckon we can do it. We're going to split the mixture into three
and colour some red, leave some plain and colour the last section green. Pull each of the colours just like we have
done before to make them opaque. And then stretch the red one to make three
long snakes, return one to the oven to warm up. And once it is soft and pliable, place it
across the top of the two red snakes and shape it at the top into a point. Add some white along each side of that triangle
and then flip it up the other way and add a strip down the centre on the top. And then finally add more white so that the
red is completely covered. Warm your green, and stretch it out and add
it over the top of the white so that it goes all the way around. Now you are going to need to place that back
in the oven to warm it up because those two red ones are quite cold by now. And once it's warm you can just stretch that
candy out into a long strip. Now to cut it without it shattering it needs
to be quite warm so return it to the oven until you can bend it like this. And then quickly using a sharp knife, chop
off pieces to reveal the little heart inside. Subscribe to How To Cook That for more crazy
sweet creations, Click here for the recipe and here for my
chocolate truffles and here for my YouTube channel. Make it a great week and I'll see you on Friday.

uHNDsUfjSnc: [Music] how to make homemade hard candy these days you can buy candies by the bulkan groceries supermarkets and nearby convenience stores but what you are probably not aware of is the fact that you can make your own hard candy at home given the right ingredients in some tools and equipment that you probably already have in your kitchen you can add these old-fashioned hard candies to your gift baskets for a change instead of just putting cupcakes and pastries in them if you are ready to make your own candies at home here are the steps on how to make homemade hard candy 1 prepare the following ingredients and equipment 2 cups of sugar 3/4 cup of hot water 2/3 cup of light corn syrup 1/8 tsp flavoring of your choice food coloring 1 large saucepan 1 candy thermometer greased cookie sheet or candy molds kitchen scissors to make sure that you have the proper temperature for making candies it is crucial to create homemade hard candies in optimal temperatures that is around 60 to 68 degrees Fahrenheit with low humidity your candy will not turn out successfully if the weather is too hot or extremely humid and rainy even your altitude can affect the outcome of the candy you may need to make adjustments if you live in a high altitude area if you have suboptimal temperature conditions you may want to compensate by cooking the candies 1 to 2 degrees higher than what is recommended in the recipe 3 combine the corn syrup sugar and water in the large saucepan stir the ingredients over medium heat until the sugar is dissolved which takes about 5 minutes afterwards you can leave it alone and let it boil for another five minutes to ensure even heating it is best to do this on a burner that is wider than the saucepan you are using for once your mixture is boiling raise the heat to high to make sure that you are hitting the right temperature attach a candy thermometer to the saucepan however make sure that the thermometer does not touch the base of the saucepan and your pan must be tall enough so that the thermometer does not reach its bottom when hung on the pan lip if you do not have a candy thermometer you may get a glass of ice-cold water to use as your gauge 5 right before the mixture reaches 300 degrees Fahrenheit add the food coloring and flavoring to the mixture you do not need to stir the mixture as the boiling action is enough to thoroughly incorporate the color and flavor 6 when the mixture reaches 300 degrees Fahrenheit remove it from the high heat immediately or it will burn if you do not have a candy thermometer drop a tiny bit of the candy mixture into the glass of ice cold water if the drop solidifies and floats to the surface then your mixture has reached the required temperature it is okay if the temperature in the saucepan continues rising as long as you were removed it from the heat 7 pour the mixture onto a greased cookie sheet and spread it around the sheet be quick as it will be hard to spread the mixture once it cools down if you want to give your candies a consistent shape you may pour the mixture in candy molds or mini muffin pans do not refrigerate as it will make your candies harden too quickly 8 wait for 30 minutes to an hour for the candy to harden if you used a cookie sheet cut the candy into several pieces using kitchen scissors 9 store the homemade hard candies and paper bags or metal tins learning how to make homemade hard candy is best done during the cold season as it complies with the optimal temperature for making candies during the holiday season you can also wrap these candies individually and include them as part of your gift baskets for your loved ones [Music]

flavoring once the mixture is evenly blended he pours it onto a cooling table the candy maker has several flavorings at his disposal from eucalyptus oil to fruit flavors he also chooses from a wide on a heated table to slow the hardening process so that the candy will remain pliable now they create the design they form various shapes and sizes and like a puzzle put the pieces together to make a
